title: Here's why it's pointless to queue outside Britain's flagship Apple store to get an iPhone 6s
text:
Here's why it's pointless to queue outside Britain's flagship Apple store to get an iPhone 6s 10:53, 25 Sep 2015 Anger as campers who spent day in the cold are sent away - whilst online pre-order customers get straight to the front of the queue Share Get daily news by email Invalid e-mail Thanks for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later iPhone fans (L) are seen camped outside the Apple Store in Covent Garden 
People who had pre-ordered the iPhone 6s waited just minutes to become the first to get their new mobile phones at Apple's flagship store today - whilst fans who had camped out for days were sent away and told to come back later. 
Security guards and people in the queue told Mirror Online the pre-order customers had been ordered to the front, whilst campers were either shunted back or given a reservation slot and told to come back later. 
Whilst the online customers looked washed and warm, with many popping in before work to get their phone, some of the people who had been waiting longer were shrouded in blankets and looking thoroughly miserable. 
We saw no sign of the people with tents outside the store, who were told to leave early this morning and given a reservation allowing them to jump the queue later this morning, when the rush had died down. 
The video below shows the total absence of the tents which were a fixture at less prominent stores around the country. Watch this video again Watch Next 
At the iStore on London's glittering Regent Street, the person at the front of the queue was a South African tech journalist who had booked a place earlier in the month. 
Moey Shawsh, 31, was the first person let into the Regent Street store today, where customers were greeted by whooping, high-fiving Apple staff. 
He said: "I showed up at 5am [three hours before opening time, because I had a reservation." 
About one hundred metres behind him, a group of three men clad in blue blankets had been waiting since 5pm yesterday. 
They told us Apple had told campers to go away, but they decided to disobey the order and stay in line whilst people who had spent much less time waiting were ushered into the store. Alamy Apple fans, yesterday. This morning this group and their tents could not be seen near Apple's flagship store 
Sam Kurdi, a 20-year-old business student from Ilford, East London, said: 
"It was cold last night, like, you wanted to die. 
"We love iPhone, we have fun as well. 
"We were having fun yesterday night, [so we decided to stay after being offered a reservation and being asked to go away]. 
"I saw lot of people go, init? A lot of the queue left after that." 
One man who did not want to be named said: "It seems unfair that we weren't the first to get in." Watch this video again Watch Next 
We spoke to one very happy-looking customer who was about to pick up his new phone after waiting less than half an hour, who didn't appear to think it was unfair that he had been placed ahead of campers. 
"It's the age of the internet and I booked online, " he shrugged. Peter Macdiarmid/LNP iPhone fans (L) are seen camped outside the Apple Store in Covent Garden 
Two years ago, it is understood the Crown Estate, which owns Regents Street were unhappy with the impromptu shanty town which formed outside the famous road's glitzy high-end fashion stores . 
Photos from last year's event show that tents were erected right outside the store on Regent Street before the event, with some campers claiming to have spent weeks under canvas. View from Rhizome HQ of tents already outside the Regent Street Apple Store: pic.twitter.com/QI52K3LdFQ — Team Rhizome (@rhizomepr) September 9, 2014 View from Rhizome HQ of tents already outside the Regent Street Apple Store: pic.twitter.com/QI52K3LdFQ — Team Rhizome (@rhizomepr) September 9, 2014 Have these campers outside the Regent Street Apple Store been tipped off about an imminent release? @MacRumors pic.twitter.com/muixITGVCo — Joshua Preston (@jpfpreston) September 9, 2014 
This year, Apple fans did set up camp on Hanover Street, next to the flagship iStore, but there was no sign of them on the road this morning when the shop flung open its doors. 
It is not known whether it asked Apple to remove the tents and the tech firm refused to comment. 
Meanwhile, press had been told to go to Covent Garden, where the first person to get their phone was someone who had camped out for more than two days. 
Sam Shaikh, a 29-year-old from Stratford, was the first to receive his phone having braved the elements since 8.30pm on Monday night. SWNS Camping equipment belonging to customers who have queued for several days lies on the floor of the Apple store in Birmingham. September 25 2015. 
Student Callum Edward-Williams, 22, from Birmingham, was the first to get an iPhone 6s at the Birmingham store, where he had also waited for two days in the cold. 
Callum said: "I've queued for every new iPhone that's been released since the 4S. 
"I was first in line this morning and purchased the 64GB 6S Plus model in rose gold. 
"I'm definitely very loyal to Apple. I think the staff must recognise my because I'm here for every launch day. 
"I'm queuing with my friends, and we take it in turns with the other people in the queue to go for toilet breaks and to get food. 
"We're like a little Apple family." 
We asked Apple for comment but it did want to discuss the campers.
